abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Our study aims to investigate an intrinsic link underlying sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which remains inconclusive in observational settings.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Summary statistics were collected from the largest GWAS(s) on SHBG adjusted for BMI (SHBG<jats:sub>adj</jats:sub>BMI; <jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>overall</jats:sub> = 368,929; <jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>men</jats:sub> = 180,094; <jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>women</jats:sub> = 188,908), crude SHBG (<jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>overall</jats:sub> = 370,125; <jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>men</jats:sub> = 180,726; <jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>women</jats:sub> = 189,473), and RA (<jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>case</jats:sub> = 22,350; <jats:italic>N</jats:italic><jats:sub>control</jats:sub> = 74,823). A genome-wide cross-trait design was performed to quantify global and local genetic correlation, identify pleiotropic loci, and infer a causal relationship.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Among the overall population, a significant global genetic correlation was observed for SHBG<jats:sub>adj</jats:sub>BMI and RA (<jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$r_{{\text{g}}}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                    <mml:msub>
                      <mml:mi>r</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mtext>g</mml:mtext>
                    </mml:msub>
                  </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> = 0.11, <jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 1.0 × 10<jats:sup>−4</jats:sup>) which was further supported by local signal (1q25.2). A total of 18 independent pleiotropic SNPs were identified, of which three were highly likely causal variants and four were found to have effects on both traits through gene expression mediation. A putative causal association of SHBG<jats:sub>adj</jats:sub>BMI on RA was demonstrated (OR = 1.20, 95% CI = 1.01–1.43) without evidence of reverse causality (OR = 0.999, 95% CI = 0.997–1.000). Sex-specific analyses revealed distinct shared genetic regions (men: 1q32.1-q32.2 and 5p13.1; women: 1q25.2 and 22q11.21-q11.22) and diverse pleiotropic SNPs (16 in men and 18 in women, nearly half were sex-specific) underlying SHBG<jats:sub>adj</jats:sub>BMI and RA, demonstrating biological disparities between sexes. Replacing SHBG<jats:sub>adj</jats:sub>BMI with crude SHBG, a largely similar yet less significant pattern of results was observed.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Our cross-trait analysis suggests an intrinsic, as well as a sex-specific, link underlying SHBG and RA, providing novel insights into disease etiology.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This was a secondary analysis of existing, publicly available summary-level GWAS data. The statement of ethics for each GWAS can be found elsewhere, approved by relevant ethics committees.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

title: A genome-wide cross-trait analysis identifies genomic correlation, pleiotropic loci, and causal relationship between sex hormone-binding globulin and rheumatoid arthritis
